title: Newcastle ‘Killer clown’ jailed for chasing pregnant woman
text:
Michael March (pictured) was dressed as a 'killer clown' and brandishing an axe when he chased a pregnant woman
An axe wielding 'killer clown' prankster has been jailed after he chased a pregnant woman the night before Halloween.
Michael March, 18, is thought to be the first person imprisoned following the craze that swept across the UK last year.
Newcastle Crown Court heard he terrified a couple walking past him after banging the foot long axe on the floor in South Shields on October 30, 2016.
The woman, who was 22 weeks pregnant, threw a brick at him in an attempt to defend herself before he ran off.
Jailing him for six months, Judge Jamie Hill QC said: 'Brandishing an axe and threatening people in the street is serious whatever the context.'
March, from Gateshead, ran off with a friend after the 'prank' but was arrested after he was traced by police using CCTV.
He was one of several arrested in the lead up to Halloween last year during a spate of 'killer clown attacks' across the country.
Vic Laffey, defending, said March suffered with behavioural disorder ADHD and 'never intended to hurt anybody'.
Jailing the 18-year-old (pictured left outside court and right in his police mugshot) for six months, Judge Jamie Hill QC said: 'Brandishing an axe and threatening people in the street is serious whatever the context'
He added: 'This was a prank that has gone horribly wrong and it is something that he regrets.
'This is his first offence and he is at low risk of offending again, he lives at home with his grandparents and is a carer for his granddad.
'He had been attending college but that has been put on hold pending the outcome of this case. 'He admits what he has done was reckless and stupid.'
Nicholas Rooke, prosecuting, told the court March claimed to have been the victim of a similar killer clown related incident in Gateshead and that resulted in him carrying on the prank.
March was one of several arrested in the lead up to Halloween last year during a spate of 'killer clown attacks' across the country (stock photo)
He said: 'He and his friend had been scaring people with the clown mask when they noticed a couple in the town centre.
'He banged the axe on the floor in order to scare them, before the woman picked up a piece of brick.'
The court heard how the victim did not make an official complaint about the incident because she was 22-weeks pregnant.
Jailing him for six month, Recorder Jamie Hill said: 'Carrying a real axe and threatening innocent people goes beyond anything that is acceptable at Halloween. 'Wearing a clown mask is not an offence but you had armed yourself with an axe, not a fake axe, a real one. 'The fact you were wearing a clown mask in an aggravating factor.'
March was ordered to pay a statutory surcharge and the axe was ordered to be destroyed.
Sentencing him, Judge Hill added March had committed a serious offence and only a custodial sentence was appropriate.
'The fact you were wearing a clown mask is an aggravating factor because it increased the fear they would have experienced and secondly it was a way of disguising who you were,' he said.
March had previously admitted possession of a bladed article.
'KILLER CLOWNS': THE BIZARRE CRAZE THAT SWEPT BRITAIN The 'killer clown' craze swept the UK in the lead up to Halloween 2016.
It involved people dressing up in clown costumes, brandishing weapons and jumping out on unsuspecting strangers.
The first sightings were reported on October 4 last year and few areas of the country escaped the craze.
It led to a deluge of calls to Childline from youngsters left terrified by the sinister phenomenon as well as dozens of reports to police.
In October in Manchester two people dressed as clowns (pictured) jumped on the car of events organiser Kurtis Mulvaney
A 10-year-old boy in Plymouth was threatened by a clown who jumped out of a bush carrying a hammer.
In Workington, Cumbria, a clown brandishing an axe chased an 11-year-old girl.
Kent Police saw 59 clown-related incidents between October 7 and 10, and Thames Valley Police had 14 reports in 24 hours.
South Yorkshire Police said it had received 61 reports or complaints.
